item_names.activatable_foodraw_mushroom_bay_bolete_: a shiver runs through you. You remember the Feast of Zeb, the grotesque excess of the gluttonous demon and his maggots devouring the land. Yet, this humble mushroom endured, untouched. You recall Demira’s quiet smile as she recognized its resilience—one of the few gifts of Creation that Zeb could not defile.
item_names.activatable_foodraw_mushroom_berserker_h: you hear echoes of laughter, of rituals in the lost halls of Atlantis. Were you there? You doubt it... The priests believed consuming this mushroom would reveal glimpses of the Divine’s mind. But you know better—those who glimpsed too much never returned the same.
item_names.activatable_foodraw_plum_hpregen_5_Local: you recall the Fay orchards, where these plums grew in perfect harmony with the land. Demira once carried a handful in her palm, offering them to those who would listen. "Patience," she had said, "is the shield against despair." You feel the lingering touch of that lesson, as if the fruit remembers her words.

item_names.building_prop_sign_utility_symbols_moon_: You feel a gentle, refreshing breeze, hear a distant melody, a song whispering at the edge of your hearing—and a name: Meirothea...
item_names.crafter_chopping_block_1_LocalizationMys: a whisper stirs in your mind: <italic>This was the first altar, after the loss of Paradise.</>
item_names.crafter_cooking_camp_fire_1_Localization: you hear the echo of a lullaby once taught by Meirothea, sung in a language now lost.
item_names.crafter_weaving_loom_1_LocalizationMyste: a whisper stirs, the voice of Saint Nectarine perhaps? <italic>In every woven thread, a fragment of grace.</>
item_names.item_material_enchanting_extract_crude_L: the sap shivers, and you feel the pull of something ancient, wounds that are not yours, grief that burns like sap drawn from bark.\nA voice calls, warm and breaking, yet powerful. Another snarls from beneath. Low guttural, older than the world itself.
item_names.item_material_enchanting_extract_exquisi:
the resin pulses in your hand and the vision overwhelms you.
You feel Demira’s strength flowing through your limbs as you plunge an amber spear into a colossal, gaping maw.
Burning blood sears your flesh, a scream like tearing stone shatters your breath.From the darkness, curses echo. Beelzebub’s guttural promise to devour Creation when freed.
Your essence splinters, your spirit fractures, merging with the spear as it roots into glowing amber veins that still bleed beneath Lyonesse, forever binding his hunger between worlds.
item_names.item_material_enchanting_extract_fine_Lo: you start to see shapes in the liquid. You see a giant woman... Demira...\nThe Third Redeemer stands, her hand aflame, driving a spear of amber through the throat of a monstruous head.\nThe blood scream and hurls. Molten hunger dropping from the wound.
item_names.item_material_enchanting_powder_crude_Lo: you catch glimpses of old prayers, half a benediction, part of a psalm, words carved by hurried hands as the great constructs rose over Lyonesse. A faint shadow lingers here, a memory of zeal and untempered ambition.
item_names.item_material_enchanting_powder_exquisit: the pearl feels warm in your hand. One surviving rune reads <italic>lux vincit tenebras</>, light conquers darkness. Another is too scarred to know if it was blessing or blasphemy. \nThe stone remembers faith torn in two: one path to safeguard Creation, another to release what lies beneath.
item_names.item_material_enchanting_powder_fine_Loc: the stone hums softly. Letters long faded now shine in short bursts, like candlelight in a dark nave. Fragments speak of salvation and sacrifice, though it’s unclear whether they were meant to bind corruption... or set it free.
item_names.item_material_lime_mortar_LocalizationMy: you remember an old saying you heard a lot when you were young: <italic>By Demira’s grace, may every stone find its place, and every hand leave behind a trace.</>

item_names.item_raw_material_enchanting_shard_Local: a shadow clings to the stone, whispering of past grandeur. The script speaks of the glorious era of the Papacy: zeal, triumph, divine ambition. Yet beneath it, something darker stirs, tainting the blessing carved upon its face.

You recognize the pattern instinctively—it is the mark of Demira, the symbol she pressed into the land itself. Once, this mushroom grew near her temples, a silent offering of sustenance for those who walked in her footsteps.
item_names.resource_static_plant_tree_branch_Locali: the twisting form of the branch tells of seasons endured, each bend a record of storms weathered and the unyielding reach toward the sky.

item_names.treetype_Alpine_Juniper_Tree_Large_01_Lo: The almost colorless smoke of burning juniper was said to drive evil spirits away.
item_names.treetype_Beech_Common_Old_01_Inner_Local: Stories say that druids sometimes made their home in old beech forests.
item_names.treetype_Beech_Common_Old_01_Outer_Local: You recall that in ancient times, beech trees were called "fays".
item_names.treetype_Beech_Common_Old_02_Inner_Local: This imposing giant of the woods makes you wonder if this very Beech Queen is the mythical consort to the Oak King?
item_names.treetype_Beech_Common_Old_02_Outer_Local: You have heard somewhere that in old Gallian dialects, beech trees are still called "fays".
item_names.treetype_Birch_Adult_01_Outer_Localizati: You recall having heard that animals herded with birch sticks become fertile and have healthy offspring.
item_names.treetype_Birch_Adult_02_Outer_Localizati: As pagan lore would have it, the birch is associated with the land of the dead, death itself and returning from the grave.
item_names.treetype_Eerie_Pine_Old_01_Inner_Localiz: You recall stories of dryads from the Fay realm gathering and transform into Pines to escape the eye of God.
item_names.treetype_Eerie_Pine_Old_01_Outer_Localiz: In this place where the edges and contours of the world seem unclear, the pine's alleged connection with dreams becomes obvious.
item_names.treetype_Eerie_Pine_Old_02_Inner_Localiz: You have heard that some of these gloomy pines may mark the burial sites of heroes of old.
item_names.treetype_Eerie_Pine_Old_02_Outer_Localiz: You recall stories of dryads from the Fay realm emerging from these old pines to torment lost travelers.
item_names.treetype_Hawthorn_Tree_Haunted_Large_01_: You recall old children stories describing old Hawthorns as gateways to wonderous, enchanted worlds.
item_names.treetype_Hawthorn_Tree_Haunted_Medium_01: You recall old children stories describing old Hawthorns as gateways to the gates of Hell.
item_names.treetype_Hawthorn_Tree_Large_01_Localiza: Ancient Hawthorn trees are by some, believed to have grown and endured in response to a holy person performing their magic.
item_names.treetype_Hawthorn_Tree_Medium_01_Localiz: No trees are as connected to stories of the Fay, as the Hawthorn
item_names.treetype_Oak_Common_Old_01_Inner_Localiz: It is said that all false Gods end their days buried under an oak.
item_names.treetype_Oak_Common_Old_01_Outer_Localiz: You recall having heard of ancient and revered oaks being given names as the enduring landmarks they are.
item_names.treetype_Oak_Common_Old_02_Inner_Localiz: You wonder if this old and mighty tree was ever given a name by someone who's life it touched.
item_names.treetype_Oak_Common_Old_02_Outer_Localiz: If the oak king loves the sound of leaves rustling in the wind, there is little wrong with the forest.
item_names.treetype_Oak_Haunted_Adult_01_Inner_Loca: It is said that the Oak is tied to wisdom and old knowledge. You shudder at the thought of what this twisted tree has seen.
item_names.treetype_Oak_Haunted_Adult_01_Localizati: Acorns and oakleaves have always had strong relation to heroism in battle, symbolizing strength and endurance.
item_names.treetype_Oak_Haunted_Adult_02_Inner_Loca: You recall that in ancient texts, the same word "duir" is sometimes used for both "oak" and "door".
item_names.treetype_Oak_Haunted_Adult_02_Localizati: It is said that to all pagan gods who controlled thunder and lightning, the oak was considered sacred.
item_names.treetype_Silver_Fir_Old_01_Inner_Localiz: It is said that the Druids of old celebrated winter solstice under the branches of the Silver Fir.
item_names.treetype_Silver_Fir_Old_01_Outer_Localiz: You recall saintly tales of pagan deities being imprisoned in large fir trees. What if...
item_names.treetype_Silver_Fir_Old_02_Inner_Localiz: It strikes you that the "silver" it its name may indicate a connection to stories of Meirothea, the second redeemer.
item_names.treetype_Silver_Fir_Old_02_Outer_Localiz: In some parts of Gallia, in the darkest days of winter, it is tradition to bring a young fir tree and branches into the home, as a reminder of the coming spring.
